definitions.text:
Spunge
1. A porous marine substance, found adhering to rocks, shells, etc. Under water, and on rocks about the shore low water. It is generally supposed to be of animal origin, and consists of fibrous reticulated substance, covered by soft gelatinous matter, but which no polypes have hitherto been observed. It is so porous as to imbibe great quantity of water, and is used for various purposes the arts and surgery.
2. In gunnery, an instrument for cleaning cannon after discharge. It consists of cylinder of wood, covered with lamb skin. For small guns, it is commonly fixed to one end of the handle of the rammer.
3. In the manege, the extremity or point of horse-shoe, answering to the heel.Pyrotechnical spunge is made of mushrooms or fungi, growing on old oaks, ash, fir, etc. which are boiled water, dried and beaten, then put strong lye prepared with saltpeter, and again dried an oven. This makes the black match or tinder brought from Germany.SPUNGE,

1. To wipe with wet spunge; as, to spunge slate.
2. To wipe out with spunge as letters or writing.
3. To cleanse with spunge; as, to spunge cannon.
4. To wipe out completely; to extinguish or destroy.SPUNGE,

1. To suck or imbibe, as spunge
2. To gain by mean arts, by intrusion or hanging on; as an idler who spunges on his neighbor.
